unnormalised: Okay, so you're planning a trip and need an address? LOL. Figuring out hotel addresses in India can be an adventure in itself, almost as exciting as the actual trip (almost!). I once tried finding a hotel near, and I quote from the website, “opp. Hanuman Temple, Mumbai.” Opp. Hanuman Temple, people! There are approximately 7.4 million Hanuman temples in Mumbai. Narrow it down, guys!

I once tried finding a hotel near, and I quote from the website, "opposite Hanuman Temple, Mumbai." Opposite Hanuman Temple, people! There are approximately seven point four million Hanuman temples in Mumbai. Narrow it down, guys!

unnormalised: Anyway, the thing about Indian addresses is they're more like suggestions than hard-and-fast rules. You might get something like "C/o Sharma Niwas, Lane No. 4, Behind Pizza Hut, Andheri (E), Mumbai, 400069." Which, if you're lucky, is actually near a Pizza Hut. Pro Tip: The pizza may or may not be edible.

unnormalised: Then there's the whole "landmark" thing. "Near the big banyan tree" is all well and good... until the big banyan tree gets chopped down for a flyover. Suddenly, your GPS is weeping and you're wandering around asking random chai wallahs, "Excuse me, *where* is the Hotel Magnificent? They said it was next to the tree that was older than my grandfather!"

unnormalised: Hotel confirmations often have these gems. Like “#12/3A, 1st Floor, Above Syndicate Bank, Jayanagar 5th Block, Bangalore, 560041”. Now, try explaining to your auto-rickshaw driver that you need to go to the *first* floor, above the Syndicate Bank. He’ll probably just stare at you blankly, then quote you 3X the normal fare. They see foreigners + complicated address = jackpot.

unnormalised: Don’t even get me started on postal codes. You'd think 6 digits would be enough to pinpoint a location, right? Wrong. Sometimes, two buildings on the same street have different postal codes. It’s like the Indian postal service is playing a very elaborate game of hide-and-seek.

unnormalised: Seriously, though, the best way to find a hotel in India? Call them. And then call them again. And maybe send a carrier pigeon with a map drawn by a local artist. Just kidding (sort of). But seriously, talk to someone. Get detailed directions. Landmarks AND nearby bus stops. Ask if they’re near any *current* landmarks (the banyan tree situation still haunts me).

unnormalised: Also, check Google Maps *street view* before you go. See if the place actually exists. I once booked a "luxury resort" that turned out to be a pile of bricks and a very optimistic sign. Lesson learned.

unnormalised: And remember the golden rule of Indian travel: Patience is your friend. And a good sense of humour is your best weapon. Happy travels! And may your hotel be *exactly* where the confirmation email says it is (but don't bet on it). You'll need that humor. Good luck finding "#420, Funky Street, Opposite Dominos, Delhi, 110001. "
